Since most of the other judges in Texas were also Woodmen, Neff decided to choose female lawyers, who were ineligible for lodge membership. Nellie Robertson was named special chief justice, and Edith Wilmans and Hortense Ward served as special associate justices.

On this day in 1925, Governor Pat M. Neff appointed an all-woman state Supreme Court, the first in Texas and probably in the nation. The case before the court involved the Woodmen of the World. All three justices belonged to this organization and were consequently disqualified.

Lastly, we must be modest about what we can know.
Ninth, US leadership continues to be essential.
Eighth, there is still a West (a term based more on shared values than geography), and alliances remain a critical instrument to promote order.
Seventh, the potential for the internet to empower individuals to challenge governments is far greater in democracies than in closed systems.
Sixth, democracies obviously face their share of challenges, but the problems authoritarian systems face may be even greater.
Fifth, the phrase “international community” needs to be retired. There isn’t one.

Fourth, economic sanctions, in many instances the instrument of choice for the West and its partners when responding to a government’s violations of human rights or overseas aggression, rarely deliver meaningful changes in behavior.
Third, integration, which has animated decades of Western policy toward China, has also failed.

Second, the idea that economic interdependence constitutes a bulwark against war, because no party would have an interest in disrupting mutually beneficial trade and investment ties, is no longer tenable.

I hope you’ll join me in celebrating all things Texas at the 136th annual Texas State Fair!

And of course we can't forget the centerpiece, the Cotton Bowl!

When it was built back in 1930, the fair reports that it cost $328,000, or $5.8 million in today’s money. The stadium now holds 100,000 people.

To get the more than 2 million expected visitors to the fairgrounds, DART will stop at Fair Park more than 800 times in 24 days.

All those folks play a lot of games - in fact, they’ll walk away with about 400,000 plush prizes worth about $1.3 Million!

Texas State Fair icon, #BigTex, is 55 feet tall — 3 feet taller than he used to be before catching fire in 2012.

He wears a size 96 Lucchese boot and jeans with a 20-foot inseam which weigh 100 pounds!

Did you know that more than 500,000 corndogs will be sold at the fair this year?

And the Fair estimates that they’ll hand out 2 million packets of ketchup!

I'm excited to be in Dallas and at opening day of the #StateFairofTX today, which has celebrated all things Texas for 130 years!

As the Fair begins, I wanted to share a few Funky Facts! ⬇️

The DOD Inspector General found that “[a]s a result of the NCTC not vetting Afghan evacuees against all available data, the United States faces potential security risks if individuals with derogatory information are allowed to stay in the county.”

The DHS OIG report follows on a report earlier this year from the DOD Office of Inspector General, which found that Afghan evacuees were not vetted by the National Counter-Terrorism Center (NCTC) using all Department of Defense data prior to arriving in the Continental US.

The IG noted that “during the initial months of OAW, screening and vetting requirements were decided on an ad hoc basis. DHS and CBP did not have standardized formal policy documents and instead could only provide informal flowcharts, meeting minutes, and draft documents.”

Furthermore, CBP admitted or paroled evacuees who were not fully vetted into the United States, and did not maintain a list of Afghans who were admitted or paroled into the United States without proper identification.

Some information that was used to vet evacuees through U.S. government databases, including name, date or birth, identification number, and travel document data was inaccurate, incomplete, or missing.

On September 8, 2022, the DHA Office of Inspector General published a report on screening, vetting, and inspection of Afghan evacuees. According to the OIG report, CBP “did not always have critical data to properly screen, vet, or inspect the evacuees."

Under the Treaties of Velasco Zavala was appointed a peace commissioner to accompany Santa Anna to Mexico City, but returned to his home in poor health shortly thereafter. He resigned the vice presidency on October 17, 1836.

Zavala's legislative, executive, ministerial, and diplomatic experience, together with his education and linguistic ability, uniquely qualified him for the role he was to play in the drafting of the constitution of the Republic of Texas.

When he learned that Santa Anna had assumed dictatorial powers in 1834, Zavala denounced his former ally, resigned his post, and eventually went to Texas. Although he first advocated the cause of Mexican Federalism, he soon became an active supporter of the independence movement.

In the 1820s he helped establish a republican government in newly independent Mexico, but was forced into exile in 1830. Zavala returned to Mexico in 1832 and was named to serve as the first minister plenipotentiary of the Mexican legation in Paris.

His support of democratic reforms led to his imprisonment in 1814 in Veracruz, where he gained enough knowledge from reading medical textbooks to qualify him to practice medicine upon his release in 1817. He also taught himself to read English during his imprisonment.
On this day in 1836, Lorenzo de Zavala, the first vice president of the Republic of Texas, died. Zavala was born in 1788 in Mexico. @TxStHistAssoc
